qas.question: Why was Prince Hall Freemasonry formed?

answers.text: refusal of early American lodges to admit African-Americans

qas.question: When was Prince Hall Freemasonry formed?
What happened when the UGLE was formed in 1813?

answers.text: U.S.-based Lodges were stricken from their rolls

qas.question: What did Africian Lodge, Number 459 become after they were removed from the UGLE?
What was Africian Lodge, Number 1 considered after they changed from Africian Lodge, Number 459?
What exists today because of the refusal of early American lodges to admit African Americans?
In what year was Prince Hall admitted into the British military lodge?
When was the African Lodge, number 459, formed?

plausible_answers.text: refusal of early American lodges to admit African-Americans

qas.question: Why was Prince Hall Freemasonry outlawed?
When was Prince Hall Freemasonry forgotten?

plausible_answers.text: U.S.-based Lodges were stricken from their rolls

qas.question: What happened when the UGLE was formed in 1913?
What was African Lodge, Number 3 considered after they changed from African Lodge, Number 456?
What no longer exists today because of the refusal of early American lodges to admit African Americans?

context: <a5_0><b14_0>Prince Hall Freemasonry<b14_0/><a5_0/> exists because of the <a0_0><b10_0>refusal of early American lodges to admit African-Americans<b10_0/><a0_0/>. In <a1_0><a6_0><b11_0>1775<b11_0/><a6_0/><a1_0/>, an African-American named Prince Hall, along with fourteen other African-Americans, was initiated into a British military lodge with a warrant from the Grand Lodge of Ireland, having failed to obtain admission from the other lodges in Boston. When the military Lodge left North America, those fifteen men were given the authority to meet as a Lodge, but not to initiate Masons. In <a7_0>1784<a7_0/>, these individuals obtained a Warrant from the Premier Grand Lodge of England (GLE) and formed African Lodge, Number 459. When the UGLE was formed in <a8_0>1813<a8_0/>, all <a2_0><b12_0>U.S.-based Lodges were stricken from their rolls<b12_0/><a2_0/> – due largely to the War of 1812. Thus, separated from both UGLE and any concordantly recognised U.S. Grand Lodge, African Lodge re-titled itself as <a9_0>the <a3_0>African Lodge, Number 1<a9_0/><a3_0/> – and <a4_0><b13_0>became a de facto "Grand Lodge"<b13_0/><a4_0/> (this Lodge is not to be confused with the various Grand Lodges on the Continent of Africa). As with the rest of U.S. Freemasonry, Prince Hall Freemasonry soon grew and organised on a Grand Lodge system for each state.
